caption_original:
On December 5, Canada became the first country to sign a Technical Arrangement for Maintenance with Japan.  This means that each country:
‚Ä¢ Accepts the aircraft and equipment maintenance safety standards of the other
‚Ä¢ No longer needs to conduct double inspections
‚Ä¢ Will reduce industry costs
‚Ä¢ Will see growth in their aviation industries
Robert Sincennes, of Transport Canada Civil Aviation, and Mitsuo Kawakami, of the Japan Civil Aviation Bureau of the Ministry of Land, Infrastructure, Transport and Tourism, signed the agreement at Transport Canada headquarters in Ottawa.  It will come into effect in February 2018.
caption_cleaned: On December , Canada became the first country to sign a Technical Arrangement for Maintenance with Japan. This means that each country: ‚Ä¢ Accepts the aircraft and equipment maintenance safety standards of the other ‚Ä¢ No longer needs to conduct double inspections ‚Ä¢ Will reduce industry costs ‚Ä¢ Will see growth in their aviation industries Robert Sincennes, of Transport Canada Civil Aviation, and Mitsuo Kawakami, of the Japan Civil Aviation Bureau of the Ministry of Land, Infrastructure, Transport and Tourism, signed the agreement at Transport Canada headquarters in Ottawa. It will come into effect in February .

caption_original:
SAFETY NOTICE: Watson Lake, Yukon
Transport Canada is doing work on the ice surface of Watson Lake, Yukon near the Watson Lake Airport. From December 2017 to January 2018, small sections of the ice will be open to allow access to the lake bed. Open water near the airport will be clearly marked with fencing until the work is done, and the lake has safely frozen over. Be very careful in this area.
This work is part of Transport Canada‚Äôs efforts to remove contamination from past commercial and military activities that were not understood as harmful at the time.
To learn more, please contact Holly Poklitar, Environmental Officer, Transport Canada at 204-688-3872.
caption_cleaned: SAFETY NOTICE: Watson Lake, Yukon Transport Canada is doing work on the ice surface of Watson Lake, Yukon near the Watson Lake Airport. From December to January , small sections of the ice will be open to allow access to the lake bed. Open water near the airport will be clearly marked with fencing until the work is done, and the lake has safely frozen over. Be very careful in this area. This work is part of Transport Canada‚Äôs efforts to remove contamination from past commercial and military activities that were not understood as harmful at the time. To learn more, please contact Holly Poklitar, Environmental Officer, Transport Canada at -688-3872.

Ready to roll in Whistler!
Building healthy and accessible communities with more environmentally friendly technology was the goal of a BC Transit project which saw the launch in Whistler today of a compressed natural gas fueling station and 25 compressed natural gas powered buses.
